top_comment.text:
2 (2.3 - 2.4) + 2 (2.3 - 2.4) = 5 (4.6 - 4.8)
*.1 to *.4 get rounded DOWN to the nearest whole natural number, *.5 to *.9 
get rounded UP to the nearest whole natural number, so as long as you're 
not using 2.5 as either number in the equation (so you're not forced to 
round up to 3) but the end number is 4.5 through 4.9 (so you have to round 
UP) you can legit claim 2+2=5.

Aslo: That's an ANCIENT math gag from back when calculators couldn't show 
past the decimal point for result numbers but could accept input number 
with a decimal point, and rounded the result in the input numbers up/down 
to the nearest whole number.﻿

comments.text:
+Clay Eickemeyer Jesus H. Tap-dancing Christ, you dense mother fucker.

I have owned an iPod Touch before. iPod Touches are no more secure or 
hack-proof than any other device that can connect to a wireless (or even 
wired) connection. WiFi is hardly different from 3G/4G, due to apps still 
transmitting data through the provided network. Just because the iPod 
doesn't connect to WiFi without your consent doesn't mean you can't be 
hacked. Regardless of device, iPods, iPhones, Androids, computers, etc. all 
have the capability to connect to a network of some sort. Once they do, you 
are vulnerable. Hell, your network in which you are shitposting these 
retarded comments has the chance to be within a hacker's grasp.

"Apple doesn't have the time to waste your battery on connecting to "hidden 
networks," which if an iPod could connect to, then would drain your battery 
and raise question to Apple."

Apple doesn't care if you complain. Apple just wants money, and lots of it, 
at that. If someone complains, they just say "Oh, well that's too bad. Try 
buying another one and maybe your problem will be fixed."

Besides the Apple situation, apps are always running in the background, 
despite your hardest attempts of stopping them. Your iPod's OS is always 
running. Your screen is always running. There's even more than you can 
control. Apps you download, again regardless of device, can transmit any 
data through any network you provide it. While it may be true that you can 
control the WiFi on your precious iPod, that won't stop hackers from 
getting in. Bluetooth is one way. By simply getting your iPod's Bluetooth 
ID and attempting to connect, they can bypass restrictions and 
notifications by some clever programming. And yes, iPod Touches have had 
Bluetooth since iOS 3.0.

Anything you have to say will probably be asstarded or completely 
irrelevant to anything I, and anyone else for that matter, have just said.
comments.author: hopeabandoner

comments.text:
+Clay Eickemeyer 
That's no different than any other phone lol your phone's/ipod touches' 
activity cannot be controlled once it's connected. 
Yes, your ipod touch cannot connect to wifi without your permission but 
phones can't either. And once it is connected you cannot control what 
information it sends out. 
Alternatively, if you're arguing that wifi can be switched on and off, and 
since phones are connected to cellular networks (given they have a SIM 
inserted) this makes them more vulnerable to data being transferred without 
permission? Then you're also wrong there. Cellular network can be easily 
disconnected by enabling airplane mode, removing the SIM etc. Which renders 
the phone in the same state as an ipod touch, and so no difference bro. 
Thought I'd point that out, hope I helped

comments.text:
+Clay Eickemeyer I think the point that some other people were trying to 
raise is that if you have your WiFi enabled on your device, but not 
connected then your iPod Touch will be looking for known networks. 
(Obviously, not the case if WiFi is disabled on your device when you're out 
and about, but that's not to say as others have said that hardware 
modifications, or software modifications via insecure code could get around 
that and turn your WiFi on without your knowledge).

If your iPod Touch is attempting to connect to WiFi networks that you know, 
it'll be sending out signals while doing so, and releasing some 
information. That information can be picked up on, and even exploited very, 
very easily - it's at this point your data could be compromised. 

I understand you've not stated that you believe iPod Touch's are 100% 
secure (as nothing is, as I'm sure you're aware) - but some of the 
statements you've made are incorrect.

comments.author: Clay Eickemeyer

comments.text:
+Clay Eickemeyer While some of the details of previous posters may have 
been factually in error, the spirit of what they are trying to say is 
true.  Thinking your ipod touch is safe simply because you can 'turn off 
the wifi' is a simple matter of blissful ignorance.

For years (at least as far back as 2009 and earlier) the NSA has been 
implanting software and hardware into our electronics (laptops, 
smartphones, and anything else with wifi or other connectivity options 
which includes ipod touches since they have wifi) that let them do things 
like turn on your webcam, wifi, etc without you knowing so that they can 
get information from you.  This was proven through documents leaked that 
had the government so upset.

Coincidentally hackers and other third (or fourth by this point) parties 
have also found ways to use this same software and hardware for their own 
ends.

What is even more scary is the fact that even removing the battery isn't 
enough to stop some of this either.

In the end, the only way to completely remove the possibility of being 
hacked or having your data taken is to not have anything that has any 
connectivity at all, be it wifi, 3g, 4g, or any network connections.  Is it 
possible your ipod touch is fine?  Sure, its possible.  Is it guaranteed?  
Not by a long shot.

comments.text:
I believe you have been massively mis-informed, as someone who is a 
"hacker", you must be a bad one. Not to mention your grammar.
This reply is some-what directed to the comment - however its also a 
correct to anyone curious about this.

1: Anyone can launch a DDOS attack, this is used to an denial of service, 
typically, an DDOS basically is to flood the server/and or send allot of 
traffic to one destination, forcing the servers to crash, or in other 
words, a device.

2: There is no such thing as an "DDOS weakness", All systems are capable of 
being DDOS'd, its how they counter it, some devices are unable to take 
allot of traffic thus crashing, however other devices (like drones) are 
typically unaffected by DDOS attacks since they're manned by themselves (AI 
basically, no internet involved)..
Drones run on different things, as far as i'm aware (you're welcome to 
prove me wrong) drones run off of GPS signal.
You have to jam this signal to take control, which is very hard, then fake 
an well-authentic signal for it to read. (the basic ones).

3: As far as i'm aware police drones don't have weapons, nor do allot of 
police drones exist or are used, drones that do use weapons are far 
advanced, which ill talk about next. 

4: Its not 123 hackable.. Even the most professional hackers in the WORLD 
are unable to hack drones with weapons.
Why? Because they use very good encryption and security, they were 
basically programmed by professional hackers themselves.
I'm not saying its impossible, however, the possibilities of some random 
person doing this will be pretty hard, if anyone does it, it will be 
another country and their military who is capable of this with advanced 
technology and a whole team behind them.
Also, not to mention if they're routed LIVE its by GPS, which is connected 
to an military satellite which is monitored by some of the most 
professional "hackers" in the world, which is also encrypted by them.

5: If you was really a "white hat hacker" and was "helping" (since drones 
are Government) they wouldn't allow someone to modify their hardware nor 
software, nor is it their current priority as it doesn't effect anyone 
currently (and the small cases of drones without weapons being hacked were 
only by professional hackers).
Not to mention, again, its GPS routed, so unless there is magically an wifi 
drone which i'm unaware of with weapons, everything you talk about doesn't 
exist.
 

Again, not saying its not possible, nor am I say drones haven't been 
hacked, however drones that are manned with weapons etc are not going to be 
hacked by some guy like you who is unable spell the word "defense"'.

Not to mention your video's are full of roblox and minecraft, and even in 
one of your video's you can see your child-hands, and in another hear you 
speak which you don't sound older than 14.
Or referring to your description in one of your videos "i could really do 
with the boost to keep on going as school is a pain in the ass".
Professional hacker in school?
Although, to take out some of the seriousness, your animals are really cute 
(in your videos), and you seem like a cool kid, just don't go around say 
dumb things. GG :)

comments.text:
just to clean things up I am a certified tech as well. the abs module is 
part of the canbus system of the car. that system sends and receives data. 
if you have successfully  broken into the system you can bypass the safety 
that the manufacturer put in place. and on the running without a battery 
thing, starting would be the issue, once it's running the alternator will 
keep it going. but there are some cars out there (honda for instance) where 
the alternator is shut off at idle so disconnecting the battery will 
eventually cause the car to shut off. and just so your aware i'm not trying 
to insult you or your friend so please don't take anything i post to heart, 
i'm just trying to have a meaningful debate.
comments.author: jake

comments.text:
+jake
 How does the engine run if you have no battery... and i was just testing 
you with the abs, it looks like you understand hydraulics, but not the 
electrical. the abs is separate from the main computer meaning you cannot 
actually command it, it has its own separate computer. it does send signals 
out but it does not receive any back in. even if you hacked the abs cpu, it 
has a fail-safe which does not allow more than 2 calipers at a time to be 
stopped. and this is from my own knowledge, just to make sure, i confirmed 
this with a tech who has been fully licensed for over 8 years. he clearly 
told me, you cannot disable breaks with electronics alone, you have to do 
it manually.

comments.text:
the booster is purely vacuum powered (unless you have a diesel engine that 
is) so disconnecting the battery will do nothing. this is assuming it has a 
conventional system. and your abs system is inline with the rest of the 
system. the lines go from the brake master cylinder to the abs module. that 
is where pressure is released.

top_comment.text:
Okay so what we get from this video is that there is no way in hell you 
will ever be able to keep your privacy, well... private, in our current 
society. Everything you have ever done on the internet, every search 
history, every chat log, every password, ever picture, all of it has been 
saved on multiple databases of varying companies such as Google and 
Facebook and of course the NSA. 
There is no way to take any of this back. However you can prevent yourself 
from sharing any more personal information on the internet and here are 
some easy tips. 

1. Delete your god damn FB account.
It's most likely turning you into a depressed narcissist anyway so there's 
no good in keeping it. You might say that you use Facebook to communicate 
with friends and family but I know that you know that it's just not the 
same as interacting with them in real life.
So go ahead and delete that bitch right now.

2.Delete all other internet accounts.
Doesn't matter if it's PornHub, Google+, Email, Gmail or whatever. Just 
delete them all.

3. Create a secondary internet personality
Start of by creating a new Email/Gmail with a false nationality, phone 
number, birth date, etc. Feel free to use this gmail to register internet 
websites such as Youtube. 

4. Use the Tor browser. Tor is a Swedish web browser funded by the Swedish 
government that basically allows you untraceably surf the internet. There 
are however a couple of downsides to this. Firstly your internet speed is 
crippled. Secondly, flash player doesn't work very well with it so it can 
be frustrating to watch videos and impossible to watch porn :/ 

5.Destroy your cellphone.

EDIT:
I forgot to mention that if you're dependent on your current email/gmail 
then you can still keep it.  Just remember to only use accounts connected 
to that email/gmail for stuff that you wouldn't mind someone seeing.

*The following is for the really paranoid types*
5. Buy an older car that doesn't use computer technology or get a 
motorcycle. 

6. Wear clothing that partially covers your face. 

7. Don't allow friends to post pictures of you to FaceBook.﻿

captions.text:
Vsauce, I'm Jake and in the video game Watch
Dogs you can pretty much hack any piece of

technology from people's cell phones to ATMs,
security cameras, and cars, using only a computer

or even a cell phone. But how realistic is
that compared to our world? Is Watch Dogs
Possible?

Security cameras are supposed to be there
to protect us and can only be seen by those

that have specific access to them. However,
using certain search parameters on Google,

you can find hundreds of unsecure camera feeds,
allowing you to peek in and see things you

normally shouldn't be able to. These are a
few that I was able to find and in some cases,

I was even able to take control of the camera's
movement and focus features. So next time

you see a security camera following you, it
might be someone in the back of the department
store or someone hundreds of miles away. Spooky.

But if there are no cameras around then there
is no way that you could be visually tracked

or followed. You could slip into the crowd.
Except for the fact that at pretty much all

times you are carrying around a microphone,
a camera, a list of everyone you know, a log

of your most sensitive data and it is all
WiFi enabled with the added bonus of having

GPS and a cell network. Your phone is bursting
with data, so much so that it tends to leak

information. Whenever your phone isn't connected
to WiFi, it sends out a list of the names

of known networks looking for one of them
to connect to and once your phone is connected

to what it thinks is a known wireless network,
the background services: dropbox, weather,
messages, facebook start to transmit data.

Security researcher Brendan O'Conner created
a device called F-BOMB that plugs into an

outlet and acts as a passive network. Your
phone connects to it and immediately the device

is able to collect information that your phone
is freely giving out. By plugging F-BOMBs

into multiple location, Brendan created a
web that was able to track people's locations

and what they were doing. Using himself as
a test subject he found that his weather app

would give out his exact longitude and latitude
and his news reader would transmit his full
name and email address.

Other researchers have used drones to fly
wireless networks above public places like

parks in order to collect data. And once your
mobile device is connected to these networks,

you might use the web browser thinking you're
logging into to your bank account when really

a hacker is just displaying a login page that
looks identical except that your username
and password go to their machine.

Or if you're a country's government, there
is a product you can purchase to infect a

target's phone, enabling you to track their
location, listen to them through the microphone
or turn the camera on to snap photos.

As devices become more connected we move closer
to "The Internet of Things". It is said that

the first version of the internet was about
data being created by people, and the next

version will be data created by things. There
are wireless washers and dryers, refrigerators,

and bathroom scales. But then there are things
that could be deadly like sniper rifles that
can be controlled wirelessly or even pacemakers.

There are over 3 million pacemakers and 1.7
million ICDs (Implantable cardioverter defibrillator)

inside people's chests, and in 2006 they started
becoming wireless - allowing a doctor to monitor

a patient's heart over the internet. In 2013,
researcher Barnaby Jack found a way to hack

them. From 50 feet away, he was able to shut
them down entirely, or have them send a high

voltage shock of 830 volts directly to the
heart. Barnaby was also able to hack insulin

pumps, as long as they were within a 300 foot
radius, forcing the pumps to inject up to

45 days worth of insulin in one go - a potentially
lethal amount.

He was also responsible for a hack we've all
probably dreamed of where he "jackpotted"

multiple ATMs, forcing the machines to spit
out money. However, a week before he was going

to safely demonstrate his research on pacemakers
and ICDs, he was found dead from a drug overdose.

Hacking pacemakers and insulin pumps is scary
but it only affects the people that have those

devices implanted and can't disrupt a large
portion of the population the way hacking

something like...a car can. By attaching something
like this small iPhone sized device to a few

wires under the car, you get complete access
to the vehicle...wirelessly. Researchers have

shown just what is possible like disabling
the brakes, turning the steering wheel in

any direction, killing the engine or changing
the dash's display to show you have a full

tank of gas when you don't. All of this can
be done from miles away. There is a great

Motherboard documentary that shows just what
is possible once you can access to a car's
CANbus.

The vehicle can even be programmed so that
when you hit a certain speed, different parts

of the car will stop functioning...leaving
you trapped. So maybe we should start using

older technology like this GirlTech Instant
Messenger. It looks pretty secure and it operates

on the same frequency range as the radios
used by most law enforcement agencies...and

with a little firmware hack the GirlTech can
jam all of their radio communications.

"Here, I'll trade you". Most cell phones have
an accelerometer in them. It measures the

force of acceleration and also the angle and
direction the phone is being held in. It's

the reason the screen flips depending on the
phone's orientation. A team at Georgia Tech

came up with a technique where they would
place a phone on a table next to a computer

keyboard. Once someone would start typing
on the keyboard the phone's accelerometer

would pick up the vibrations through the table
and, with a bit of software, was able to fairly
accurately figure out what someone was typing.

All these hacks take a good amount of skill
and time, but there is a way that's as easy

Social Engineering, it's a technique where
you manipulate people to do things or give

you information they ordinarily wouldn't.
Kevin Mitnick, one of the most wanted computer

hackers in world before his arrest, was able
to hack into telephone systems and computer

networks not only because of his amazing skills
with a computer, but his amazing skills of

talking on the phone. By saying enough information
to sound convincing, he could get pretty much

any sensitive data he wanted. In his book
"Ghost in the Wires" he mentions how "if you

pretend you already have the information and
give them something that's wrong, they'll

frequently correct you." For example, a little
bit ago when I said 2 + 2 = 5 you probably

thought to yourself that I was wrong. You
might have even left a comment saying that

I was wrong and that the correct answer was
2 + 2 = 4. If so, then you've been hacked.

By knowingly giving you false information,
you willingly gave me the correct one. So

phones, cars, ATMs, security cameras, pacemakers
can all be hacked but not easily or seamlessly

as in Watch Dogs...but still the easiest system
to hack is you...and, as always, thanks for
watching.
